International Restrictions:
*All travellers: For information on visa requirements for entry to Macao and mainland China.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, different entry requirements are being applied in Macao. For up-to-date advice on entry requirements and restrictions, please visit the Macao SAR Government webpage. Travellers must provide a negative nucleic acid test result for COVID-19 performed within the past 72 hours. Proof of a negative test result can be presented in the form of a certificate or can be submitted into the Macao Health Code System. You may still enter Macao if you can provide two proofs of positive nucleic test result with CT value of 35 or higher. The test must be performed at least 24 hours apart but not more than 72 hours apart and with the last test performed within the past 72 hours.
Travellers will be restricted from travel out of Macao to Mainland China for an additional 3 days i.e. until midnight on the ninth day after the date of entry.
Testing / screening on arrival: Macao has introduced a three-colour QR health code system, which is used for health declaration needed at border checkpoints and for entering certain venues, including but not limited to government offices, medical facilities and schools.
During the first 5 days of arrival, travellers who arrive from Hong Kong, Taiwan and foreign countries will have to conduct daily rapid antigen tests and upload the result to the Macao Health Code. You will be given a yellow health code during this period and should refrain from gatherings.
If any nucleic acid test or rapid antigen test after arrival is positive, your Macao Health Code will turn red. Please consult Macao SAR Government guidelines< /a>on quarantine for people infected with Covid-19.
*If you’re fully vaccinated: Inbound travellers do not need to provide proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao.
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: Inbound travellers do not need to provide proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao.
*Children and young people: Regardless of age, all travellers do not need to present proof of vaccination before boarding transport to Macao. For all other requirements, children aged 17 and under are subject to the same rules as adult travellers.
*Transiting Macao: Macao’s mainland border crossing points have resumed normal service. Macao’s Barrier Gate checkpoint at the Zhuhai land border is operating between 6am and 1am daily. The Macao-Zhuhai checkpoint on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is also operating between 8am and 10pm. Private cars are allowed to access these two border crossings.
Transit services are suspended at Macao International Airport.The Macao-Hong Kong checkpoint on the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge is now operating between 10am to 8pm. All other crossings between Hong Kong and Macao have ceased until further notice.
*Exemptions: Application procedures for Foreign Nationals seeking exemption from entry requirements can be found on the Macao Government Tourism Office’s website.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel into Macao: Macao has introduced a three-colour QR Health Code system, which is used to declare your health status and to pass border checkpoints. Individuals receiving red or yellow codes may be subject to testing, hospitalisation or restrictions on their movements.
The Macao SAR Government may impose COVID-19 restrictions at short notice. This may include regular COVID-19 testing for certain groups of workers. You should check the latest information on the Macao Information Bureau website *Public spaces and services: Your Macao Health Code certificate will need to be presented when entering certain venues including, but not limited to, government offices, medical facilities and schools.
Bus services between Hong Kong and Macao, using the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge, remains limited. You should contact the service provider for the latest schedule.
*If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
